summary: This is a formal letter from the French Ministry of Justice's International Criminal Assistance Bureau to the U.S. Department of Justice, dated March 9, 2021. It outlines French legal provisions regarding extradition, specifically stating that French nationality at the time of an alleged offense constitutes an absolute bar to extradition, and that subsequent loss of nationality does not affect this prohibition.

persons.name: Head of the International Criminal Assistance Bureau
persons.context: The signatory of the official letter from the French Ministry of Justice to the U.S. Department of Justice, explaining French extradition law.

persons.name: His Honor the Keeper of Seals, Minister of Justice
persons.context: The addressee of the letter within the French government, to whom the communication from the International Criminal Assistance Bureau is directed.

locations: Embassy of the United States of America located in Paris, France
keyFacts: French law (Articles 696 et seq. of the Code of Criminal Procedure) governs extradition proceedings.
Article 696-2 allows France to extradite non-French citizens located in France who are subject to prosecution or sentencing by a requesting state.
Article 694-4 expressly prohibits extradition if the individual had French citizenship at the time the alleged offense was committed.
French nationality at the time of the offense is described as an 'insuperable obstacle' to extradition.
Any loss of French nationality after the offense has no bearing on the extradition assessment; the critical factor is nationality at the time of the alleged crime.
